labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Is this document going to define how ephemeral hybrid shares are generated?
issues.author: dconnolly
issues.body: For example, do I create a single random seed, split it, and feed half to  X25519 keygen and the other half to Kyber768 keygen? Do each component scheme just do everything independently? The document as it stands would allow me to do both and be compliant.

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body:
Either is fine, and I do not see a reason to mandate one of them. But I could be missing something.

An aside: HPKE does require KEMs to specify their keygen explicitly, and so we do for the hybrid there in [section 3.3](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-westerbaan-cfrg-hpke-xyber768d00).

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body: Defining something is better than nothing, as someone may come up with some other deranged scheme because it was never written down; that [`DeriveKeyPair`](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-westerbaan-cfrg-hpke-xyber768d00) is pretty great

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: Most APIs won't allow you to pass the seed: the obvious thing to do then is simply call keygen for both separately, and that's perfectly fine. That is how BoringSSL [does it](https://github.com/google/boringssl/blob/f714cb2935906a2f085c3b89d7e206af94627b56/ssl/ssl_key_share.cc#L204-L207). If we mandate a certain way to generate both components, we'd have to complicate that simple approach.

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body: Fair enough, can that be made explicit? `X25519Kyber768Draft00.KeyGen() = (X25519.KeyGen(), Kyber768.keyGen())` or similar

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body:
[`draft-ietf-tls-hybrid-design`](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-tls-hybrid-design/), of which this is an instantiation writes

```
   [TLS13] requires that ``The key_exchange values for each
   KeyShareEntry MUST be generated independently.'' In the context of
   this document, since the same algorithm may appear in multiple named
   groups, we relax the above requirement to allow the same key_exchange
   value for the same algorithm to be reused in multiple KeyShareEntry
   records sent in within the same ClientHello.  However, key_exchange
   values for different algorithms MUST be generated independently.
```

Is that satisfactory or too implicit?

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body:
> [`draft-ietf-tls-hybrid-design`](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-tls-hybrid-design/), of which this is an instantiation writes
> 
> ```
>    [TLS13] requires that ``The key_exchange values for each
>    KeyShareEntry MUST be generated independently.'' In the context of
>    this document, since the same algorithm may appear in multiple named
>    groups, we relax the above requirement to allow the same key_exchange
>    value for the same algorithm to be reused in multiple KeyShareEntry
>    records sent in within the same ClientHello.  However, key_exchange
>    values for different algorithms MUST be generated independently.
> ```
> 
> Is that satisfactory or too implicit?

I will probably submit suggestions to clarify that language in draft-ietf-tls-hybrid-design too (one can possibly read 'independently' and 'different algorithms' to include the hybrid one, too), but I think it should be made explicit: in the X25519Kyber758Draft00 instantiation, this means 
`X25519Kyber758Draft00.KeyGen() = (X25519.KeyGen(), Kyber758.KeyGen())` every time, although the invocation of each component scheme may have been done once and the resulting values used in multiple `KeyShareEntry`s in one `ClientHello`. The way it currently stands, the only component value likely to be in multiple `KeyShareEntry`s is X25519, not Kyber758, so maybe making it explicit that that is an acceptable implementation of this document would be helpful.

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body:
> > [`draft-ietf-tls-hybrid-design`](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-tls-hybrid-design/), of which this is an instantiation writes
> > 
> > ```
> >    [TLS13] requires that ``The key_exchange values for each
> >    KeyShareEntry MUST be generated independently.'' In the context of
> >    this document, since the same algorithm may appear in multiple named
> >    groups, we relax the above requirement to allow the same key_exchange
> >    value for the same algorithm to be reused in multiple KeyShareEntry
> >    records sent in within the same ClientHello.  However, key_exchange
> >    values for different algorithms MUST be generated independently.
> > ```
> > 
> > Is that satisfactory or too implicit?
> 
> I will probably submit suggestions to clarify that language in draft-ietf-tls-hybrid-design too (one can possibly read 'independently' and 'different algorithms' to include the hybrid one, too), but I think it should be made explicit: in the X25519Kyber758Draft00 instantiation, this means 
> `X25519Kyber758Draft00.KeyGen() = (X25519.KeyGen(), Kyber758.KeyGen())` every time, although the invocation of each component scheme may have been done once and the resulting values used in multiple `KeyShareEntry`s in one `ClientHello`. The way it currently stands, the only component value likely to be in multiple `KeyShareEntry`s is X25519, not Kyber758, so maybe making it explicit that that is an acceptable implementation of this document would be helpful.
> 

(Not ignoring the KEMTLS work but you know)

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: Ok, let me know when it lands in `hybrid-design`, and then we can add an appropriate remark here.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: I think that it is better that I just let you get the sole credit here.  Happy to have had you suggest it, but I'm trying not to sign on to lots and lots of work.

pulls.title: Clarify value lengths, tidy up IANA section
pulls.author: chris-wood
pulls.body: @bwesterb the length of the server encapsulation and shared secret is likely wrong, so please suggest the correct values!
